column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0003] A light emitting diode (LED) is a semiconductor optical device capable of producing light in the infrared, visible or ultraviolet (UV) region.
#Text=LEDs emitting in the visible and ultraviolet are made using gallium nitride (GaN) and its alloys with indium nitride (InN) and aluminum nitride (AlN).
#Text=These devices generally consist of p and n-type semiconductor layers arranged into a p-n junction.
#Text=In a standard LED device, semiconductor layers are evenly grown onto a polished substrate such as GaAs or sapphire.
#Text=A typical semiconductor layer is composed of gallium nitride (GaN) that has been doped to be a p or n-type layer.
#Text=[0004] Important figures of merit for an LED are its internal quantum efficiency (IQE) and light extraction efficiency.
#Text=For a typical LED the IQE depends on many factors, such as the concentration of point defect, Auger processes and device design.

#Text=In the case of nitride LEDs grown along polar (0001) and (000-1) directions the internal efficiency is also reduced due to the distortion of the quantum wells between the n- and p-doped layers caused by the internal electric fields.
#Text=The light extraction efficiency of standard LEDs based on GaN is determined from Snell's law to be 4% per surface.
#Text=An LED commonly includes several quantum wells made of a small energy gap semiconductor (well) and a wider bandgap semiconductor (barrier).
#Text=Visible LEDs employ indium gallium nitride (InGaN) as the well and GaN as the barrier.
#Text=Ultraviolet LEDs employ AlGaN of different compositions as both wells and barriers.
#Text=The IQE of an LED device based on nitride semiconductors grown along polar direction is reduced by electric fields across its quantum wells.
#Text=This phenomenon is referred to as the quantum confined Stark effect (QCSE).
#Text=The QCSE affects LED light emission by red shifting the emission wavelength and reducing photoluminescence intensity.
#Text=The rather small value of light extraction efficiency in the standard LED is the result of the high refraction index of the semiconductor layer at the exit interface.
#Text=[0005] A number of approaches have been proposed to enhance the extraction of light from LEDs.
#Text=For example, in GaAs LEDs, the extraction of light is affected by the absorption of the emitted light in the GaAs substrate.
#Text=To mitigate this problem, one can use epitaxial lift-off and wafer bonding methods to transfer the GaAs LED structure to transparent substrates.
#Text=Another approach involving the optimization of LED surface geometry (such as the truncated inverted pyramid), combined with the use of substrate mirrors, has pushed the extraction limit to 30%.
#Text=Other approaches involve the use of a continuously variable refraction index transparent material to reduce the back-reflection at the interface.
#Text=Some of these approaches have some manufacturing limitations and the last one suffers from fast index-material degradation with time.
#Text=[0006] An approach that is recently becoming increasingly attractive is photon extraction from randomly micro-textured thin film surfaces.
#Text=It has significantly improved extraction efficiency, with record external quantum efficiencies of 44% demonstrated at room temperature for GaAs based LEDs (Windish et al., 2000).
#Text=In this reference, the textured surface was formed after the growth of the LED using lithographic methods.
#Text=It turns out that, even in that case, most of the photons are still extracted from within the emission cone inside the critical angle corresponding to a flat surface.
#Text=Consequently there is still a wide room for improving extraction well beyond the present values.

#Text=[0007] Visible and UV LEDs based on GaN and other III-nitride materials are used widely for full color displays, automotive lighting, consumer electronics backlighting, traffic lights, and white LEDs for solid state lighting.
#Text=A variety of approaches are used towards formation of white LEDs.

#Text=One approach is the utilization of three-color LEDs (RGB) and an alternative approach using hybrid methods such as UV LEDs in combination with a tri-color phosphor or blue and blue/red LEDs with two or one color phosphor.
#Text=Current white LED performance has reached 30 lm/W, while efficiency more than 200 lm/W is required for commercially attractive semiconductor lighting.
